Description: Pottery feeding flask in the form of a stitched leather ball, marked on the exterior with incised pentagons with stich marks in the grooves; wheel-made with applied details; small conical spout off the shoulder; small double-rib handle with a snake in relief, its neck and head twisting towards the rim, its tail descending from the handle; on the base is a rosette in relief; groove around the mouth, possibly for a lid which is now missing; made of buff clay with a light orange slip, burned or fired black in places.
Curator's comments: The snake motive on the handle might also have a medical or chthonic significance. For a similar ball shape, but with a trefoil spout and more elaborate decoration, see GR 1893,11-1.1 (BM Vase G86).
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola
